Literature Review: The advent of DNA-editing enzymes as base editors has revolutionized the field of genetic engineering, offering unprecedented precision in the modification of DNA sequences. This literature review explores the design and application of these enzymes, focusing on their repurposing and engineering to achieve targeted genetic modifications. The development of clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeat-associated (CRISPR-Cas) systems has been pivotal in directing the activity of DNA-editing enzymes to specific genomic loci, thereby enhancing their utility in genetic research and therapeutic applications (Jinek et al., 2012). Among the DNA-editing enzymes, deaminases have been extensively engineered to convert one nucleobase into another, enabling the introduction of point mutations without inducing double-strand breaks (Komor et al., 2016). This approach has been particularly useful in correcting point mutations associated with genetic disorders. Glycosylases, on the other hand, have been repurposed to excise specific bases, facilitating the study of DNA repair mechanisms and the development of base excision repair-based therapies (Krokan & Bjørås, 2013). Methyltransferases and demethylases have been engineered to add or remove methyl groups from DNA, respectively, offering a means to modulate gene expression epigenetically (Luo et al., 2018). The engineering of these enzymes has involved a combination of rational design and directed evolution, leading to the development of base editors with enhanced specificity, efficiency, and reduced off-target effects (Gaudelli et al., 2017). The application of these base editors extends beyond basic research, with potential therapeutic applications in the treatment of genetic disorders, cancer, and infectious diseases (Rees & Liu, 2018). Moreover, the ability to modulate gene expression epigenetically opens new avenues for the treatment of diseases caused by dysregulated gene expression. The collective engineering efforts in the development of base editors serve as a model for the repurposing and engineering of other enzyme families, highlighting the potential of protein engineering in advancing biomedical research and therapy (Anzalone et al., 2019). Despite the remarkable progress, challenges remain in ensuring the safety and efficacy of base editors in clinical applications, necessitating further research to optimize their design and application (Doudna & Charpentier, 2014). In conclusion, the design and application of DNA-editing enzymes as base editors represent a significant advancement in genetic engineering, offering powerful tools for precise genetic modifications and opening new possibilities for therapeutic interventions.
